metadata.title: Semantic Design of Academic Documents
metadata.description: A comprehensive course on structuring, authoring, and preserving academic knowledge using modern semantic tools.

weeks.title: Introduction to Semantic Writing
weeks.subtitle: Foundations of Semantic Text
objectives: Define semantic writing and distinguish it from visual formatting.
Explain the importance of machine-readable academic documents.
Identify the core components of an academic paper.
weeks.activities: Deconstruct a PDF paper into its semantic components (Abstract, Keywords, Sections, References) using a plain text editor.

evaluation.description: Class Discussion: The longevity of PDF vs. HTML.

weeks.title: Markdown & Structured Text
weeks.subtitle: Syntax and Hierarchy
objectives: Write a complete academic essay using valid Markdown syntax.
Implement complex content structures like nested lists and blockquotes.
weeks.activities: Lab: Convert a legacy Word document into clean, semantic Markdown.

evaluation.description: Assignment 1: Submit your first semantic draft.

references.text: Gruber, J. (2004). Daring Fireball: Markdown Syntax Documentation.

weeks.title: Metadata & Frontmatter
weeks.subtitle: Describing Data with Metadata
objectives: Embed rich metadata into documents using YAML frontmatter.
Standardize author information for citation systems.
Manage document versioning through metadata fields.
weeks.activities: Workshop: Creating a unified metadata schema for a class journal.

evaluation.description: Peer Review: Check metadata completeness of partner's document.

weeks.title: Digital Preservation & Export
weeks.subtitle: Formats and Accessibility
objectives: Convert semantic source files into various publication formats.
Ensure documents meet accessibility standards (WCAG) automatically.
Discuss strategies for long-term digital preservation.
weeks.activities: Final Project: Build a multi-format export pipeline for a thesis chapter.

evaluation.description: Final Exam: Theoretical concepts and practical conversion tasks.

references.text: Library of Congress. Sustainability of Digital Formats.
